head.title: The Blanket of Spray in the Park

hedline.hl1: The Blanket of Spray in the Park

abstract.p: Dr Sanford F Kuvin letter, commenting on July 25 article on spraying of mosquitoes in Central Park, says use of pesticides should be expanded to protect exposed population from virus and other mosquite-borne diseases; drawing

block.p: Within the last two weeks, mosquitoes infected with the West Nile virus have been found not only in Central Park but also in three counties of New York and in Stamford, Conn., with infected birds that carry the virus in eight New York and New Jersey counties (''Central Park Shut to Spray for Virus,'' front page, July 25).

We are in an era of emerging diseases, and the West Nile virus is just one of a long list of old-new germs that have invaded our shores. Whether it gains a foothold in this country and continues to spread depends on adequate public health measures to eliminate the infected mosquito population.

Within the last two weeks, mosquitoes infected with the West Nile virus have been found not only in Central Park but also in three counties of New York and in Stamford, Conn., with infected birds that carry the virus in eight New York and New Jersey counties (''Central Park Shut to Spray for Virus,'' front page, July 25).

We are in an era of emerging diseases, and the West Nile virus is just one of a long list of old-new germs that have invaded our shores. Whether it gains a foothold in this country and continues to spread depends on adequate public health measures to eliminate the infected mosquito population.

There has been no evidence that the pesticides in current use cause disease in humans, and we must expand their use to protect the exposed population to the West Nile virus and other mosquito-borne diseases.
SANFORD F. KUVIN, M.D. Palm Beach, Fla., July 25, 2000
The writer is chairman, Kuvin Center for Infectious and Tropical Diseases, Hebrew University of Jerusalem.
